The selective hydrogenation of acetylene is a vital process to for the purification of crude ethylene in petroleum industry. Achieving high activity and selectivity simultaneously over Ni-based catalysts is still challenging. Herein, a partial encapsulation strategy is proposed by fabricating carbon-encapsulated Ag nanoparticles and un-encapsulated Ni nanoparticles on Al2O3 surface (Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3) toward the enhanced selectivity without loss of activity. In particular, the Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 exhibits higher ethylene selectivity of 81% at the complete acetylene conversion along with excellent stability for 30-h, in sharp with the Ni/Al2O3 (6%) and Ni-Ag/Al2O3 (54%) catalyst. The enhanced selectivity is attributed to the promotion of hydrogen spillover by the carbon species on Al2O3 surface and the inhibition of oligomer formation by a steric hindrance formed by the carbon layer on the Ag surface. This study provides a new structural design avenue of bifunctional bimetallic catalyst for selective hydrogenation reaction. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Selective hydrogenation Acetylene Selectivity Ni-based catalysts Carbon encapsulation Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ethylene stands as a pivotal cornerstone within the chemical industry, which is mainly produced from naphtha cracking and accompanied by a minor quantity of acetylene impurity (∼1%). Removing the acetylene impurity to less than 1 ppm is a critical process for purifying the ethylene feedstock since the acetylene impurity can poison the Ziegler-Natta catalysts used for ethylene polymerization, consequently compromising the quality of the polyethylene product [1–3]. Hydrogenating the acetylene impurity to ethylene product is the preferred method for this process, since this can yield additional ethylene and make the process more profitable [4,5]. This process is commonly achieved over Pd-based catalysts alloyed with a second metal (e.g., Ag [6–8], Au [9–11], Cu [12–15], Ga [16–18], In [19,20], Co [21,22], Zn [23–26]). And the Al2O3 supported Pd-Ag catalysts (PdAg/Al2O3) are widely employed in the petrochemical industry for selective hydrogenation of acetylene. Nonetheless, the Pd-based catalysts always suffer from drawbacks such as low ethylene selectivity and high costs, leading to the requirement for efficient catalytic materials from non-precious metals. The commonly used non-noble metal or metal oxide catalysts for selective hydrogenation of acetylene include Ni [27–34], Fe [35,36], Cu [37–44] and CeO2 [45–47]. In principle, the metal Ni with incomplete d-electron orbital shows excellent application prospects for acetylene selective hydrogenation due to its high ability of hydrogen dissociation [48]. Therefore, the construction of Al2O3 supported Ni-Ag catalysts with high catalytic activity for acetylene selective hydrogenation by replacing Pd with Ni is of enormous importance for industry, but still remains challenge. On the one hand, the carbonic species can bond strongly to Ni ensembles through a multi-bridge configuration to form ethylidene intermediate, which would be over-hydrogenated to ethane and/or polymerized to green oil [34], resulting in lower ethylene selectivity and fast deactivation. On the other hand, since it is difficult to form Ni-Ag alloy [49], that only individual Ni and Ag nanoparticles can be formed on the Al2O3 surface. In view of the poor capability of hydrogen spillover on non-reducible Al2O3 [50–52], the overflow of active H from Ni to Ag through Al2O3 surface is too restricted to promote hydrogenation of acetylene adsorbed on Ag surface, thereby resulting in formation of oligomer. In the previous, we found that carbon encapsulated nanoparticles can reduce the formation of oligomer by inhibiting the acetylene coupling process [53,54]. However, enhanced ethylene selectivity always comes at the cost of a loss of hydrogenation activity, which is due to the covering of the sites by carbon layer. In this work, the issue was overcome through a partial encapsulation strategy, which is achieved by only encapsulating the Ag nanoparticles with a carbon layer, while the Ni nanoparticles are exposed on the surface of Al2O3. During the acetylene hydrogenation process, acetylene and H2 are preferentially adsorbed on the surfaces of metal Ag and Ni, respectively. The carbon layer on the Ag nanoparticles can suppress the acetylene coupling to form oligomer, while the hydrogen dissociation ability of the catalyst is unaffected due to that the metal Ni is unencapsulated by carbon layer. As expected, the developed catalyst showed a remarkable catalytic efficiency in selective hydrogenation of acetylene, which was not achievable by the monometallic Ni and bimetallic Ni-Ag without the confined environment. As such, this report provides a new carbon encapsulating strategy to overcome the trade-off between activity and selectivity in acetylene selective hydrogenation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 catalysts Scheme 1 illustrates the synthetic procedure for Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 catalysts. Firstly, the Ni-Ag carbonate precursor was synthesized through a co-precipitation strategy. A solution mixture was obtained by dissolving AgNO3 and Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O in deionized water. Then the γ-Al2O3 powder was added to the above salt mixture under stirred conditions for 8 h. Then Na2CO3 was dissolved in deionized water and added dropwise into the above suspension until pH = 9 and keep stirring for another 1 h. Furthermore, the precipitate was obtained by filtration and washed with water for several times until the pH of the filtrate is neutral, followed by drying in vacuum at room temperature for 24 h to obtain the carbonate precursor. The Ni-Ag precursor was pretreated in acetylene atmosphere (10 vol% C2H2 in N2) at 120 ℃ for 2 h and calcined in N2 at 500 ℃ for 1 h to obtained NiO-Ag@C/Al2O3. Thereafter, the NiO-Ag@C/Al2O3 was reduced in H2 at 500 ℃ for 3 h, denoted as Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Power X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected from 30° to 80° by using a XRD diffractometer (PANalytical X′Pert Powder) operated with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) at a scan rate of 10°·min−1. The images of high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (TEM), energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping and scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) were obtained by Talos F200S microscope. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were collected on ESCA-LAB250Xi spectrometer with radiation of Al Kα (hv=1486.6 eV). Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) of hydrogen was conducted on Chembet-3000 instrument with a TCD detector. 2.3 Catalytic Performance Acetylene semi-hydrogenation was carried out in a fixed-bed microreactor with 0.03 g catalyst precursor under atmospheric pressure. The inlet gas mixture is composed of 0.5 vol% C2H2 and 10.0 vol% H2 with N2 balance. The composition of the reactant and product was analyzed by gas chromatography with a flame ionization detector and capillary column (30 m × 0.535 mm×15.00 µm) with N2 as the carrier gas. C2H2 conversion and selectivity to C2H4 and C2H6 were calculated as follows. C 2 H 2 conversion = Acetylene ( inlet ) − Acetylene ( outlet ) Acetylene ( inlet ) × 100 % C 2 H 6 selectivity = Ethane ( outlet ) − Ethane ( inlet ) Acetylene ( inlet ) − Acetylene ( outlet ) × 100 % C 2 H 4 selectivity = Ethylene ( outlet ) − Ethylene ( inlet ) Acetylene ( inlet ) − Acetylene ( outlet ) × 100 % 3 Results and discussion The XRD patterns of the Ni/Al2O3, Ni-Ag/Al2O3 and Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 catalysts are shown in Fig. 1. In the XRD patterns of the Ni-Ag/Al2O3 and Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 catalysts, four main peaks located at 2θ of 38.1, 44.3, 64.4 and 77.5° are attributed to the (111), (200), (220) and (311) plane reflections of metallic Ag (PDF#04–0783). In all cases, the diffraction peaks matched only with phase-pure metal Ag, and no characteristic XRD peaks associated with crystal Ni was observed, indicating the highly dispersed Ni nanoparticles with smaller gain size in the Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3, Ni-Ag/Al2O3 and Ni/Al2O3 catalysts. No shift of the peaks related to metallic Ag indicated the absence of Ni-Ag alloyed phase and co-existence of isolated Ni and Ag nanoparticles on the Al2O3 surface in the bimetallic catalysts of Ni-Ag/Al2O3 and Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3. Meanwhile, the stronger intensity of the diffraction peak related to metallic Ag in the Ni-Ag/Al2O3 catalyst indicates the larger Ag nanoparticles were formed in the Ni-Ag/Al2O3 catalyst. To further measure the particle size of the Ni/Al2O3, Ni-Ag/Al2O3 and Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 catalysts, TEM and HRTEM were carried out. As shown in Fig. 2a, Ni/Al2O3 exhibited uniform distribution of Ni nanoparticles with mean size of 3.6 nm. By closely magnifying the HRTEM images of the small nanoparticles, the lattice spacing of 0.202 nm is ascribed to the (111) plane of metallic Ni. As for Ni-Ag/Al2O3 and Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 (Figs. 2b and 2c), in addition to the smaller Ni nanoparticles with a narrow size distribution and average particle sizes of 4.2 and 4.6 nm, respectively, the lattice spacing of 0.204 nm from the larger particles is attributed to (200) plane of monometallic Ag, indicating that the larger nanoparticles are the metal Ag particles, which is consist with the XRD results. Furthermore, in comparison with the Ag particles in Ni-Ag/Al2O3 (Fig. 2b), the Ag particles in Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 were encapsulated with an obvious amorphous layer, while the surface of small particles of Ni is not encapsulated by a shell layer (Fig. 2c and S1). Raman spectroscopy was further employed to characterize the composition of the amorphous layer. It is obvious that two peaks at 1370 and 1594 cm−1 ascribed to the D band and G band of carbon materials (Fig. S2) [55,56], respectively, were observed, revealing the Ag nanoparticles were encapsulated in a carbon layer. The D band is related to the topological defects and disorders, and G band is ascribed to graphitized carbon. In addition, the ID/IG ratio of Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3, which is related to the degree of disordered/ordered structure of carbon materials, is 0.57, indicating the high graphitization degree and conductivity of the carbon layer. Above results of XRD, TEM and Raman showed that the carbon layer can efficiently suppress the aggregation of Ag nanoparticles. By analyzing the synthesis process it was concluded that the carbon-encapsulated Ag particles was originated from the decomposition of silver acetylide, which is derived from the reaction between acetylene and silver carbonate. Moreover, since it is difficult to form an alloy phase between Ag and Ni, the carbon layer is only formed on the surface of Ag. In order to detect the elemental distribution of Ni and Ag in the bimetal particles, STEM-EDS was employed and the result was shown in Fig. 3. It is obvious that Ni and Ag are not so evenly distributed in the particles, further confirming the separated Ni and Ag nanoparticles in the Ni-Ag/Al2O3 and Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 catalysts. The formation of individual Ni and Ag nanoparticles is mainly due to that it is difficult for the formation of Ni-Ag alloy, which is consist with the phase diagram and literatures [49]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were further performed to gain insight into the surface species of Ni/Al2O3, Ni-Ag/Al2O3 and Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 ( Fig. 4). The spectra in the Ni 2p3/2 region were deconvoluted mainly into three peaks. The peaks at 852.9, 855.8 and 861.6 eV are related to the metallic Ni species, Ni2+ species of NiO and satellite peaks, respectively, indicating that the presence of a fraction of Ni in oxidized state in the three catalysts. The formation of NiO is mainly attributed to the re-oxidation in air. In the Ag 3d XPS spectra of Ni/Al2O3, Ni-Ag/Al2O3 and Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 (Fig. S3), the peak at 374.1 and 368.1 eV are corresponding to the Ag0 3d3/2 and Ag0 3d5/2, respectively. Clearly, no significant shift of binding energy referred to metallic Ni and Ag species was observed, proving the absence of electron transfer between Ni and Ag, and further confirming the separated Ni and Ag nanoparticles in the bimetallic catalysts. Acetylene selective hydrogenation test was carried out using these Ni-based catalysts to gain insight into the impact of the Ag addition and carbon layer on the catalytic performance. Acetylene conversion and ethylene selectivity as a function of temperature over the Ag/Al2O3, Ni/Al2O3, Ni-Ag/Al2O3 and Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 catalysts are shown in Fig. 5a. The Ag/Al2O3 showed negligible activity in acetylene hydrogenation due to the low ability of hydrogen dissociation. Obviously, the Ni/Al2O3, Ni-Ag/Al2O3 and Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 catalysts showed comparable hydrogenation activity was observed with the temperature to achieving complete acetylene conversion of 150, 160 and 160 °C, respectively. Except for activity, ethylene selectivity to ethylene was illustrated in Fig. 5b. It is observed that Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 with carbon encapsulation displayed much higher ethylene selectivity than Ni/Al2O3 and Ni-Ag/Al2O3 in the whole temperature range of 90–190 °C. The selectivity to ethylene was enhanced evidently from 6% (Ni/Al2O3) to 54% (Ni-Ag/Al2O3) and then to maximum 81% (Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3) at complete conversion. The results revealed that the Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 was more selective than most of the Ni-based catalysts in the references (As shown in Table S1). In addition, the ethylene selectivity over the three catalysts exhibited different changing trends. The ethylene selectivity of Ni/Al2O3 decreased from 56% to 6% with increasing the reaction temperature from 90 to 190 °C, accompanied by an increase in ethane selectivity from 7% to 57% (Fig. S4a), revealing that a substantial portion of acetylene was over-hydrogenated to ethane over Ni/Al2O3, which is consisted with the characteristic of Ni-based catalysts [32]. Conversely, for the Ni-Ag/Al2O3 and Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 catalysts, a slight increase of ethylene selectivity was observed when the temperature increased from 90 to 190 °C. Meanwhile, it is obvious that almost no ethane formation was observed for the Ni-Ag/Al2O3 and Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 catalysts, in a good agreement with the characteristic of Ag catalysts for selective hydrogenation of acetylene where very minor amount of ethane was formed [57]. The results indicate that the metal Ag might be the main sites for selective hydrogenation of acetylene for the Ni-Ag/Al2O3 and Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 catalysts. The acetylene hydrogenation on Ag surface is predicated on the preferential adsorption on Ag surface. Therefore, C2H2-TPD was further employed to probe the adsorption characteristics of acetylene over Ni/Al2O3 and Ag/Al2O3 and the results were shown in Fig. S5. The peak below 150 °C corresponds to the weak π-adsorption of acetylene. Notably, the peak is observed at lower temperature for weak π-adsorption of acetylene of the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst (96 °C) than that of the Ag/Al2O3 catalyst (120 °C), confirming that acetylene would be preferentially adsorbed on the Ag surface during the acetylene hydrogenation process on the Ni-Ag/Al2O3 and Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 catalysts. As shown in Fig. S4b, the selectivity to oligomer over the Ni-Ag/Al2O3 catalyst is much higher that over the Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 catalyst, which is likely to be the main reason for the difference in ethylene selectivity between Ni-Ag/Al2O3 and Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3. The reduction in the formation of oligomer may be due to the following two reasons. On the one hand, lower hydrogen coverage may be the first factor in causing enhanced oligomer formation over Ni-Ag/Al2O3, which can switch the reaction from preferential ethylene formation to acetylene coupling [27]. For the Ni-Ag/Al2O3 catalyst, due to the separated distribution of Ni and Ag nanoparticles on Al2O3 surface, it is difficult for the active H dissociated on Ni surface to spillover to the Ag surface through the nonreducible Al2O3 [50,51], resulting in lower hydrogen coverage on Ag surface to hydrogenate acetylene to form ethylene. Therefore, it is speculated that the reduction of oligomer production on Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 may be due to the enhanced hydrogen spillover from Ni to Ag, thus promoting acetylene hydrogenating to ethylene. To validate the hypothesis, H2-TPD was employed to investigate the effect of hydrogen spillover. As displayed in Fig. S6, the higher peak area indicated that the Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited a much higher adsorption ability of H2 than that of the Ni-Ag/Al2O3 catalyst. In addition, the peak intensity of the latter peak at around 400 °C ascribed to the spillover of hydrogen over the Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 catalyst is stronger than that of the Ni-Ag/Al2O3 catalyst [58], confirming that the spillover of active hydrogen from Ni to Ag was promoted for the Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 catalyst. The EDS mapping (Fig. S7) results reveal that both elements of Ni and C were well dispersed on the catalyst surface, indicating that the Al2O3 surface is also covered with a certain amount of carbon species. Thus, the enhanced hydrogen spillover may be closely associated with the carbon species on Al2O3 surface, which may act as “bridge” for the transport of H atoms from Ni to Ag [51]. On the other hand, the previous result revealed that the carbon layer can offer a great steric hindrance for the acetylene coupling to inhibit the formation of carbon species with longer chains [53]. Thus, the composition of the oligomer over the Ni-Ag/Al2O3 and Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 catalysts was further investigated to get insight into the effect of the carbon layer on the oligomer formation ( Fig. 6). The ratio of C4 to C4+ over the Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 catalyst was around 4.65 under the acetylene conversion of 100% at 180 °C, which is much higher than that over the Ni-Ag/Al2O3 catalyst (0.48). The results indicated that the spatial confinement by the carbon layer could suppress the growth of the carbon chain into longer oligomer, which is consistent with the previous results [53]. As well-known, the stability of the catalysts for acetylene hydrogenation is closely related to the green oil deposited on the catalyst surface, especially for Ni-based catalysts. It is observed that the catalyst durability is also correlated to the carbon layer. As shown in Fig. 7, the Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited excellent stability with acetylene conversion of around 90% during the 30-h test. While, the Ni-Ag/Al2O3 catalyst deactivated quickly from 87% to 54% with activity loss of about 27% in 30-h. The enhanced stability is strongly to the lower formation of oligomer on the surface of Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3. In addition, XRD and Raman characterizations were employed to investigate the structural alterations of the catalysts before and after the reaction. The XRD results (Fig. S8a) showed that the no significant structural alterations were observed in the catalyst before and after the reaction. Meanwhile, the Raman spectrum (Fig. S8b) of the spent Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 catalyst is essentially identical to that of the fresh Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 catalyst. The results the catalyst and the carbon layer were stable during the reaction process. In addition, the catalytic performance of acetylene hydrogenation is always sensitive to the composition of the bimetallic catalysts [49]. Therefore, the influence of Ag: Ni ratios on structure and catalytic performance was further examined. The TEM images of Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3, Ni-Ag1.5 @C/Al2O3 and Ni-Ag2 @C/Al2O3 were shown in Fig. S9. All these Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 catalysts were composed of individual small Ni nanoparticles and carbon encapsulated large Ag nanoparticles. Furthermore, the catalytic performance of acetylene hydrogenation over Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3, Ni-Ag1.5@C/Al2O3 and Ni-Ag2@C/Al2O3 was investigated and shown in Fig. 8. Notably, the three catalysts displayed comparable acetylene conversion and ethylene selectivity in the whole temperature range of 90–190 °C, indicating that the Ag: Ni ratios has a minor effect on the acetylene selective hydrogenation performance, especially on ethylene selectivity. This is mainly due to the enhanced hydrogen spillover by the carbon species on Al2O3 surface and inhabitation of oligomer formation by the carbon layer on the surface of Ag particles, which facilitated the utilization of active hydrogen atom and the hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene on Ag surface, thereby greatly reducing the effect of the Ag: Ni ratios. 4 Conclusions In summary, separated small Ni nanoparticles and large Ag nanoparticles with a carbon layer were fabricated on Al2O3 surface (Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3) through a facile and efficient method. The as-obtained Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 with carbon encapsulation showed the enhanced ethylene selectivity while maintaining preferable hydrogenation activity for selective hydrogenation of acetylene in comparison with the corresponding Ni-Ag/Al2O3 catalyst without the carbon layer. The ethylene selectivity at complete acetylene conversion was as high as 81% over Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3. It is obvious that the trade-off between hydrogenation activity and ethylene selectivity was overcome through a simple process of carbon encapsulation for Ni-Ag catalysts. Detailed characterizations revealed that Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 is a dual-site catalyst that the smaller Ni nanoparticles without carbon encapsulation are the sites for adsorption and dissociation of H2 and Ag nanoparticles with carbon encapsulation are the sites for adsorption and hydrogenation of acetylene. The carbon species play a very key role in the enhancement of catalytic performance. The carbon on the Al2O3 surface may facilitate the hydrogen spillover from Ni to Ag, and the carbon layer on the Ag surface can suppress the chain growth of linear hydrocarbons by a steric hindrance. The results and conclusions pave a promising avenue for designing the Ni-based catalysts for efficiently hydrogenating acetylene to ethylene. coredata.dc:description: The selective hydrogenation of acetylene is a vital process to for the purification of crude ethylene in petroleum industry. Achieving high activity and selectivity simultaneously over Ni-based catalysts is still challenging. Herein, a partial encapsulation strategy is proposed by fabricating carbon-encapsulated Ag nanoparticles and un-encapsulated Ni nanoparticles on Al2O3 surface (Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3) toward the enhanced selectivity without loss of activity. In particular, the Ni-Ag@C/Al2O3 exhibits higher ethylene selectivity of 81% at the complete acetylene conversion along with excellent stability for 30-h, in sharp with the Ni/Al2O3 (6%) and Ni-Ag/Al2O3 (54%) catalyst. The enhanced selectivity is attributed to the promotion of hydrogen spillover by the carbon species on Al2O3 surface and the inhibition of oligomer formation by a steric hindrance formed by the carbon layer on the Ag surface. This study provides a new structural design avenue of bifunctional bimetallic catalyst for selective hydrogenation reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Partial carbon encapsulation synthesis of separated Ni-Ag catalyst for efficient selective hydrogenation of acetylene: Synergizing hydrogen spillover and steric hindrance
